title: Correlation of Bs --> μ+μ- and (g - 2)μ in minimal supergravity.
abstract: We analyze the decay mode B-s --> mu (+)mu (-) in minimal supergravity (mSUGRA). We find that the recently measured excess in (g - 2)(mu), if interpreted within mSUGRA, is correlated with a substantial enhancement of the branching ratio B (B-s --> mu (+)mu (-)): if (g - 2)(mu) exceeds the standard model prediction by 4 x 10(-9), B(B-s --> mu (+)mu (-)) is larger by a factor of 10-100 and within reach of Run-II of the Tevatron. Thus the search for B-s --> mu (+)mu (-) is a stringent test of the GUT scale relations of mSUGRA. An observation of B-s --> mu (+)mu (-) at the Tevatron implies a mass of the lightest SUSY Higgs boson below 120 GeV. B-s --> mu (+)mu (-) can also significantly probe SO(10) SUSY GUT models. \u

Thus the search for B-s --> mu (+)mu (-) is a stringent test of the GUT scale relations of mSUGRA. CERN–TH/2001-211 hep-ph/0108037
Correlation of Bs → µ
+µ− and (g − 2)µ in Minimal Supergravity
Athanasios Dedes1, Herbert K. Dreiner1 and Ulrich Nierste2
1 Physikalisches Institut, Universita¨t Bonn, Nußallee 12, D-53115 Bonn, Germany
2 CERN, TH Division, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland
We analyse the rare decay mode Bs → µ
+µ− in the minimal supergravity scenario (mSUGRA). We
find a strong correlation with the muon anomalous magnetic moment (g − 2)µ. An interpretation
of the recently measured excess in (g − 2)µ in terms of mSUGRA corrections implies a substantial
supersymmetric enhancement of the branching ratio B(Bs → µ
+µ−): if (g−2)µ exceeds the Standard
Model prediction by 4 · 10−9, B(Bs → µ
+µ−) is larger by a factor of 10–100 than in the Standard
Model and within reach of Run-II of the Tevatron. Thus an experimental search for Bs → µ
+µ−
is a stringent test of the mSUGRA GUT scale boundary conditions. If the decay Bs → µ
+µ− is
observed at Run-II of the Tevatron, then we predict the mass of the lightest supersymmetric Higgs
boson to be less than 120 GeV. The decay Bs → µ
+µ− can also significantly probe the favoured
parameter range in SO(10) SUSY GUT models.
Supersymmetry (SUSY) is an attractive and widely
studied extension of the Standard Model (SM). The min-
imal supergravity model (mSUGRA) [1] relates all su-
persymmetric parameters to just 5 real quantities: the
universal scalar and gaugino masses M0 and M1/2, the
trilinear term A0, the ratio tanβ of the two Higgs vac-
uum expectation values, and sgnµ, where µ is the Higgs-
ino mass parameter. The first three quantities are de-
fined at a high, grand unified energy scale and the others
at the electroweak scale. They are the boundary con-
ditions for the renormalization group equations, which
determine the physical parameters at our low scale. Pre-
cision observables, which are affected by SUSY correc-
tions through loop effects, play an important role in
constraining the supersymmetric parameter space. The
small number of parameters makes mSUGRA highly pre-
dictive so it can be significantly tested by low energy
precision measurements. In this letter we show that the
decay Bs → µ
+µ− is a stringent test of the mSUGRA
scenario, in particular when correlated with (g − 2)µ.
Recently the Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL)
reported an excess of the muon anomalous magnetic mo-
ment aµ = (g − 2)µ/2 over its SM value [2]. The differ-
ence δaµ = a
exp
µ −a
SM
µ = (43±16) ·10
−10 corresponds to
a 2.6σ deviation from the SM. An mSUGRA interpreta-
tion of this anomaly implies µ > 0 (in the sign convention
with M1/2 > 0 and equal signs of the diagonal elements
of the chargino mass matrix) [3]. It further invites a
large tanβ >∼ 10 [4]. The discrepancy in the case of aµ
is by itself not significant enough to justify the claim
of new physics, especially since the calculation of aSMµ
involves two hadronic quantities: the hadronic contribu-
tions to the photon self-energy, which must be obtained
from other experiments, and the (smaller) light-by-light
scattering contribution, which can only be estimated with
hadronic models. A more conservative estimate of the
latter would reduce the BNL anomaly to a 2σ effect [2].
Hence in order to resolve the possible ambiguity between
mSUGRA and alternative explanations of δaµ one ideally
wishes to study other observables whose sensitivity to su-
persymmetric loop corrections is correlated with δaµ. It
is our purpose here to show the strong correlation be-
tween B(Bs → µ
+µ−) and δaµ in mSUGRA.
SUSY modifies B meson observables if tanβ is large,
because the b Yukawa coupling becomes sizable. Espe-
cially sensitive are quantities with a b quark chirality flip
like the branching ratios B(B → Xsγ) and B(B → ℓ
+ℓ−).
In mSUGRA the low energy value for the trilinear term
At is dominated by M1/2 with At < 0 for M1/2 > 0 [5].
Then µ > 0 implies that the charged-Higgs-top loop and
the chargino-stop loop tend to cancel in B(B → Xsγ), so
that the sensitivity to mSUGRA corrections is weakened.
A further disadvantage of this decay mode is that it re-
quires an experimental cut on the photon energy, which
introduces some hadronic uncertainty.
In [5] the possible impact of flavour-blind SUSY on
other B physics observables, in particular those which en-
ter the fit of the unitarity triangle, were studied and only
small effects were found. This did not include the decay
Bs → µ
+µ−. In contrast to the observables in [5], the
branching ratio B(Bs → µ
+µ−) grows like tan6 β [6–8],
with a possible several orders of magnitude enhancement.
We here go beyond this work to study Bs → µ
+µ− in
the mSUGRA model. Since B(B → ℓ+ℓ−) ∝ m2ℓ , the
branching ratio is largest for ℓ = τ . Yet τ ’s are hard to
detect at hadron colliders, so that the prime experimen-
tal focus is on the search for Bs → µ
+µ−. B factories
running on the Υ(4S) resonance produce no Bs mesons.
Leptonic branching ratios of Bd mesons are smaller by a
factor of |Vtd/Vts|
2 <
∼ 0.06. Since in B factories the boost
of the Bd meson is known and the considered leptonic
decay rates can be substantially enhanced over their SM
values in SUSY, we encourage our colleagues at BaBar
and BELLE to look for Bd → τ
+τ− decays, as well.
From now on we restrict ourselves to the decay mode
Bs → µ
+µ−.
In [6–8] the SUSY corrections to B(Bs → µ
+µ−) were
calculated at the one-loop level. For large tanβ, higher
order corrections can be large, eventually of order 1.
In [9] tanβ-enhanced supersymmetric QCD corrections
1
have been summed to all orders in perturbation the-
ory. We have incorporated these dominant higher or-
der corrections by replacing the b Yukawa coupling hb ∝
mb tanβ with h
eff
b = hb/(1+∆mb), where ∆mb ∝ µ tanβ
depends on the gluino and sbottom masses and can be
found in [9]. ∆mb is positive for µ > 0. The dominant
contribution to B(Bs → µ
+µ−) is proportional to heff 4b ,
so that the inclusion of ∆mb tempers the large-tanβ be-
haviour.
The considered branching ratio can be expressed as
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) =
6.0 · 10−7

. (1)
Here |Vts| = 0.040 ± 0.002 is the relevant CKM ma-
trix element and fBs = (230 ± 30) MeV [10] is the
Bs decay constant. In (1) we have kept the depen-
dence on the lepton mass mµ, so that the generalisa-
tion to Bd → τ
+τ− is straightforward. The Wilson
coefficients CS , CP and CA, which contain the short-
distance physics, are normalised as in [11]. The co-
efficients cS , cP and c10 defined in [8] are related to
ours by CS = −2cS sin
2 θW , CA = −2c10 sin
2 θW and
CP = 2cP sin
2 θW . Within the SM, CS and CP are
negligibly small and the NLO result for CA can be
well approximated by CA = 2.01(mt/167 GeV)
1.55 [12].
Here mt ≡ mt(mt) is the top quark mass in the MS
scheme. mt = 167 GeV corresponds to a pole mass
of mt = 175 GeV. The SM prediction is given by
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) = (3.7 ± 1.2) · 10−9, with the uncer-
tainty (±25%) dominated by fBs . This is also the main
hadronic uncertainty in the SUSY calculation.
During Run-I of the Tevatron, CDF determined [13]
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) < 2.6× 10−6, at 95% C.L. (2)
The single event sensitivity of CDF at Run-IIa is es-
timated to be 1.0 · 10−8, for an integrated luminosity
of 2 fb−1 [14]. Thus if mSUGRA corrections enhance
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) to e.g. 5 · 10−7, one will see 50 events
in Run-IIa. Run-IIb may collect 10-20 fb−1 of integrated
luminosity, which implies 250-500 events in this example.
In SUSY, the dominant coefficients are CS,P since
they are proportional to tan3 β. We would like to un-
derstand the effect of the restricted mSUGRA param-
eters on CS,P and thus on B(Bs → µ
+µ−). In
mSUGRA the low-energy values of both µ and the
squark masses are dominated by the (GUT scale) value
of M1/2 through the renormalization group equations.
For not-too-large M0,M1/2 <∼ 500 GeV and A0 ≃ 0
GeV we can derive the approximate formula B(Bs →
µ+µ−) ≈ 10−6 tan6 βM2
1/2GeV
4/(M2
1/2 +M
2
0 )
3. In the
vicinity of the maximum (near M1/2 = 0.4M0) the
approximate formula is not accurate. A similar esti-
mate of the supersymmetric contribution to aµ yields
(δaµ)SUSY ∝ tanβf(M0)/M
2
1/2. (δaµ)SUSY depends on
slepton masses, which are less sensitive to M1/2 than
squark masses; they are dominated by M0. We have en-
coded the M0 dependence in the slowly varying function
f(M0). Hence both B(Bs → µ
+µ−) and (δaµ)SUSY
grow with tanβ and decrease with increasing M1/2. For
this it is essential that we have made the assumption
of the mSUGRA GUT scale boundary conditions. Thus
within mSUGRA we expect a strong correlation between
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) and (δaµ)SUSY : if δaµ 6= 0 requires a
SUSY explanation with large tanβ then we would expect
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) to be strongly enhanced. If, however, the
supersymmetric explanation of δaµ requires small M1/2
and a moderate value of tanβ then we would expect only
a moderate enhancement of B(Bs → µ
+µ−).
FIG. 1. (δaµ)SUSY , versus B(Bs → µ
+µ−) for tan β (top)
and M1/2=450, M0 = 350, A0 = 0, µ > 0, mt = 175
GeV. Shown also, the SM prediction, the present bound by
CDF [13], on B(Bs → µ
+µ−) as well as the present 1σ and
2σ bound on δaµ from BNL [2]. We used fBs = 230 MeV.
We now study these effects quantitatively. For this
we use the full computation of Eq.(1) including the re-
summed SUSY QCD corrections, and restricting our-
selves to the mSUGRA parameters. In Fig.1, we
show the direct correlation between B(Bs → µ
+µ−)
and (δaµ)SUSY for the fixed parameters: M1/2 =
450 GeV,M0 = 350 GeV, A0 = 0, µ > 0 and mt = 175
GeV. On the upper edge we show the tanβ dependence.
We restrict ourselves to tanβ < 58 in order to guarantee
radiative electroweak symmetry breaking (REWSB). We
have included the SM prediction and the CDF bound
from Eq.(2). The solid (dashed) curve represents the
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) result with (without) resummation of
the tanβ-enhanced SUSY-QCD corrections. In this ex-
2
ample, the resummation suppresses B(Bs → µ
+µ−) by
75% for tanβ >∼ 50. In order for mSUGRA to account
for δaµ within 1σ of the current BNL measurement at
this parameter point, we see that we need a large value
of tanβ >∼ 50. Due to the strong correlation within
mSUGRA we then predict B(Bs → µ
+µ−) >∼ 5 · 10
−8,
which is observable by CDF at Run II.
FIG. 2. Contours of B(Bs → µ
+µ−) (solid) and (δaµ)SUSY
(in units 10−10) (dashed) in the M1/2-tanβ plane. The light-
est neutral CP-even Higgs mass is shown as well (dot-dashed).
The shaded regions are excluded, as described in the text.
The mSUGRA parameters are given at the top.
FIG. 3. Contour plots of the B(Bs → µ
+µ−) (solid) and
on (δaµ)SUSY (dashed) in the (M0,M1/2)-plane for mSUGRA
parameter values as shown. The shaded regions are excluded
as described in the text. Contours of the light Higgs boson
mass (dot-dash line) are also shown.
As we discussed above, we expect B(Bs → µ
+µ−) to
dominantly depend on the mSUGRA parameters M1/2
and tanβ. In Fig.2 we show the B(Bs → µ
+µ−) (solid)
and the (δaµ)SUSY (dashed) contours in this plane. We
have fixed: M0 = 300 GeV, A0 = 0, µ > 0 and
mt = 175 GeV. The 2σ contours for δaµ (11,75) are
explicitly given. The left vertical shaded region is the-
oretically excluded since it does not allow for REWSB
or violates the LEP chargino bound. The upper right
triangular shaded region is excluded, since the LSP is
not neutral. If as expected, CDF can probe down to
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) >∼ 2·10
−7 at RUN IIa, this corresponds to
a sensitivity of (M1/2, tanβ) ranging from (160GeV, 47)
to (450GeV, 57). The qualitative discussion of before
is now nicely reproduced. B(Bs → µ
+µ−) decreases
with increasing M1/2 and rapidly increases with tanβ.
Fig.2 also nicely shows the cross-correlation between
(δaµ)SUSY and B(Bs → µ
+µ−). If both B(Bs → µ
+µ−)
and (δaµ)SUSY are found in disagreement with the SM
and are measured with a 50% and 20% accuracy, respec-
tively, then for given M0, this fixes tanβ to better than
20% and M1/2 to better than 30%.
It is conventional to discuss mSUGRA physics in
the (M1/2,M0)-plane. In Fig.3 we show the contours
of B(Bs → µ
+µ−) (solid) and (δaµ)SUSY (dashed) in
this plane, for tanβ = 50, A0 = 0, µ > 0 and
mt = 175GeV. Again we include the CDF bound
Eq.(2) and the Higgs mass contours. The left shaded
region is excluded through the requirement of REWSB
or the chargino bound. The lower right shaded re-
gion is excluded through the requirement of a neutral
LSP. A sensitivity of B(Bs → µ
+µ−) >∼ 2 · 10
−7 at CDF
now corresponds to a sensitivity of M1/2 <∼ 280GeV and
M0 <∼ 400GeV, respectively.
While CDF is not able to see squark masses directly up
to 0.7 TeV (corresponding to M1/2 = M0 ≃ 300 GeV,),
it will nevertheless be able to prepare the ground for
LHC by observing the Bs → µ
+µ− mode. Even bet-
ter, after 10 fb−1 CDF will probe M1/2 <∼ 450 GeV and
M0 <∼ 600GeV (for tanβ = 50) which in mSUGRA cor-
responds to masses for the heaviest superpartners of 1
TeV. We conclude the discussion of Fig.3 with the pre-
diction of the light Higgs boson mass Mh (dot-dashed
line) for tanβ = 50 in the mSUGRA scenario [15]. Any
measurement of B(Bs → µ
+µ−) by itself implies a use-
ful upper bound on Mh. The simultaneous information
of B(Bs → µ
+µ−) and δaµ fixes Mh in most regions of
the (M1/2,M0)-plane. A Higgs mass around 115.6 GeV
results in 10−8 <∼ B(Bs → µ
+µ−) <∼ 3 ·10
−7 which would
most likely be measured before the Higgs boson is dis-
covered.
In Figs. 1-3 we have chosen A0 = 0. A non-zero A0
changes the value of At at low energies. This parame-
ter plays a crucial role for the GIM cancellations among
the contributions of different squarks to B(Bs → µ
+µ−).
Changing A0 to −500GeV in the scenario of Fig. 1 en-
hances B(Bs → µ
+µ−) by up to a factor of 6 com-
pared to the case with A0 = 0. For A0 = +500 GeV
B(Bs → µ
+µ−) is slightly decreased.
3
In our figures we have omitted further constraints on
the mSUGRA parameter space, in order to clearly show
the correlation between B(Bs → µ
+µ−) and (δaµ)SUSY .
The most significant further constraint comes from the
measurement of B(B → Xsγ) [16], whose prediction is
less certain in the large tanβ region [17,5]. If we take
the conservative approach of [18], then we can exclude
values of M1/2 <∼ 250GeV in Fig.2 for tanβ
>
∼ 25. In the
scenario of Fig.3 this implies B(Bs → µ
+µ−) <∼ 5 · 10
−7.
For a discussion of the constraints from supersymmetric
dark matter see for example [4,18] and references therein.
The large values of tanβ we have been considering
are theoretically well motivated within SUSY SO(10)
Yukawa unification. There a narrow parameter region can
explain the observed δaµ while still being consistent with
the constraint from b→ sγ [19,20]. This is not within the
context of mSUGRA. However, in this parameter region
both µ andM1/2 are light, while the CP-odd Higgs boson
mass is less than 300 GeV, and tanβ ≈ 50. Therefore
we expect B(Bs → µ
+µ−) to be strongly enhanced. As
an example we determine B(Bs → µ
+µ−) for the best fit
points found in [20]: MA = 110 GeV, mχ˜1
<
∼ 250 GeV,
|At| >∼ 1 TeV, mt˜
<
∼ 1 TeV and tanβ ≃ 50. Within the
hadronic uncertainties B(Bs → µ
+µ−) >∼ 10
−5 which is
already excluded by CDF [13]. Thus the SO(10) models
should be reconsidered in the light of B(Bs → µ
+µ−).
Turning it around, if an SO(10) GUT model is the cor-
rect description of nature then the decay Bs → µ
+µ−
must be just around the corner.
In conclusion, we have found a striking correlation be-
tween the muon anomalous magnetic moment aµ and the
branching ratio B(Bs → µ
+µ−) in mSUGRA scenarios.
If the reported excess in aµ [2] is caused by mSUGRA
corrections with large tanβ, one faces more than an or-
der of magnitude enhancement of B(Bs → µ
+µ−) over its
SM value. This is within reach of Run-II of the Tevatron.
The combined measurements significantly constrain the
mSUGRA parameters, allowing a determination of tanβ
andM1/2. A measurement of B(Bs → µ
+µ−) will further
constrain the mass of the lightest Higgs bosons. SO(10)
SUSY explanations of the measured aµ are barely com-
patible with the present upper bound on B(Bs → µ
+µ−).
We thank B. Dutta, G. Isidori, K. Mizukoshi and X.
Tata for cross-checking our numerical results. A.D. ac-
knowledges financial support from the Network RTN Eu-
ropean Program HPRN-CT-2000-00148.
